The Ans. is Glucocerebrosidase, which is associated with Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within macrophages, resulting in cells that have a characteristic "crumpled paper" appearance when viewed under a microscope. The presence of these cells, along with symptoms like intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GALT enzyme: This enzyme is related to Galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism. It does not present with a "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow biopsies, nor is it associated with the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Pompe disease: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder due to a deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase. It typically involves muscle weakness and cardiomegaly but does not produce the "crumpled paper" cells seen in bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option D. Niemann-Pick disease: This is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it is due to sphingomyelinase deficiency. The characteristic cells in Niemann-Pick disease have a "foamy" appearance, not the "crumpled paper" appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow cells is a hallmark of Gaucher disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: What is the key mechanism leading to tissue damage in patients with prolonged diabetes? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperglycemia

 

The primary mechanism leading to tissue damage in diabetes is persistent hyperglycemia, which:

 

  • Leads to oxidative stress
  • Promotes formation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs)
  • Causes endothelial dysfunction and inflammation

 

Most microvascular complications (neuropathy, nephropathy, retinopathy) are directly attributed to chronic hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sorbitol accumulation: Plays a secondary role, particularly in diabetic neuropathy and cataracts, but is not the primary cause of damage

 

Option C. Insulin resistance: Contributes to hyperglycemia, but does not directly cause tissue damage

 

Option D. Decreased insulin secretion: Leads to hyperglycemia, but tissue damage occurs due to persistent high glucose levels

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperglycemia is the fundamental mechanism causing tissue damage in prolonged diabetes, leading to various microvascular complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer presented with fatigue and lethargy. He worked for 12-14 hours a day, and his diet pattern consisted predominantly of fast food with very little veggies and greens. Labs: Hb - 9, MCV 106. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

 

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia, indicated by an MCV of 106. Macrocytic anemia is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. The patient's dietary habits, which include a diet predominantly of fast food with very little vegetables and greens, suggest a lack of dietary folate.

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically occurs in individuals who do not consume animal products (vegans). This deficiency is less likely in this patient due to the absence of such a dietary restriction.
  • Folate deficiency: Common in individuals with poor intake of vegetables and greens. This matches the patient's dietary pattern.
  • Iron deficiency: Results in microcytic anemia (MCV < 80), not macrocytic anemia.
  • Hemolytic anemia: Usually presents as normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100) with increased reticulocyte count and elevated LDH, which does not match the lab findings of this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, it is more common in individuals who avoid animal products. The patient's history does not indicate a dietary restriction on animal products.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), which is not consistent with the patient's lab findings of an MCV of 106.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia typically presents with normocytic anemia and increased reticulocyte count, not with the high MCV seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency should be considered in patients with macrocytic anemia and poor dietary intake of vegetables and greens. This deficiency can cause fatigue and lethargy and is confirmed by a high MCV and dietary history.

choices.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulphadoxine/Pyrimethamine 750/37.5 mg (2 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulphadoxine/Pyrimethamine 750/37.5 mg (2 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from Rajasthan is diagnosed with mixed malaria infection â P. falciparum + P. vivax. Treatment regimen on Day 2 would be: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

 

In cases of mixed malaria infection involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, the treatment approach differs from that of single-species infections.

 

For mixed infections, the primaquine dose is adjusted to 2.5 mg to target both liver and blood stages effectively, while artesunate is used to clear the parasitemia. Artesunate is typically given for three consecutive days, and the dosage of primaquine is reduced compared to when treating only P. falciparum, where the standard dose would be 7.5 mg. This regimen helps in managing mixed malaria effectively, ensuring both species are adequately targeted.

 

Note â

 

  • For patients from other parts of the country, ACT-SP (artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) plus primaquine is used.
  • For patients from northeast India, artemether-lumefantrine combination therapy is preferred.
  • Primaquine in mixed infections is given for 14 days, while in single infections, it is given only on the second day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mixed malaria infections involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, primaquine 2.5 mg is used on Day 2 along with artesunate to effectively treat both species.

questions.text: Where is use of this instrument contra-indicated? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obstructed labor

 

  • This image shows an obstetric forceps. 
  • Forceps are contraindicated in obstructed labor because attempting instrumental delivery in this condition would be dangerous and fatal. In obstructed labor, the fetus cannot descend through the birth canal due to mechanical obstruction, making it a direct indication for cesarean section. Any attempt at instrumental delivery could cause serious maternal and fetal trauma.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cesarean section: Incorrect. Forceps can be used during cesarean section, especially with a mobile free-floating head. For deeply engaged heads, one blade of the forceps can be used to dislodge the head.

 

Option B. After coming head of breech: Incorrect. Piper's forceps are specifically designed and commonly used for delivering the after-coming head in breech deliveries.

 

Option D. Occipito posterior: Incorrect. Forceps can be safely used in occipito posterior position. The baby will be delivered face-to-pubis, but both forceps and vacuum extraction are acceptable options.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Obstructed labor is an absolute contraindication for instrumental delivery (both forceps and vacuum) and is a direct indication for cesarean section.
